comments.summary: Check for the existence of a binary

structure.name: checkForBinaryWithCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { checkForBinaryWithCancel } from 'bloodline'
import { fork } from 'fluture'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  checkForBinaryWithCancel(
    cancellationFn,
    'gvpr',
    ['-V'],
    ''
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Check for multiple binaries in a single call

structure.name: checkForBinaries
structure.example:
```js
import { checkForBinaries } from 'bloodline'
import { fork } from 'fluture'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  checkForBinaries(
    cancellationFn,
    '/usr/bin',
    { gvpr: ['-V'], dot: ['-V'] }
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Generate a dependency tree, given a config, a directory, and a filename

structure.name: plant
structure.example:
```js
import { plant } from 'bloodline'
const tree = plant({}, '../..', '../monocle/cli.js')
```

comments.summary: Test whether a path includes `'node_modules'` within it.

structure.name: isNodeModule
structure.example:
```js
import { isNodeModule } from 'bloodline/tree'
isNodeModule('./node_modules/ramda') // true
```

comments.summary: Test whether a path includes `'.git'` within it.

structure.name: isGitPath
structure.example:
```js
import { isGitPath } from 'bloodline/tree'
isGitPath('.git/config') // true
```

comments.summary: Grab an id from a cache if possible

structure.name: getId
structure.example:
```js
import { getId } from 'bloodline/tree'
const basePath = '..'
const cache = {}
const key = 'a'
console.log(getId(basePath, cache, key)) // 'bloodline/a'
```

comments.summary: Take a dependency tree and recursively walk it, returning a grouped set of dependencies.

structure.name: groupTree

comments.summary: Take a dependency tree and recursively walk it, returning flattened set of dependencies.

structure.name: flattenTree

comments.summary:
Automatically create many of the fundamentals needed to build robust CLI tools,
including help text.

structure.name: configurate

pageSummary: A Future-wrapped `fs` API, for future-based, lazy, easy-to-model asynchrony that makes it easy to manipulate the file system.

comments.summary: @pageSummary A Future-wrapped `fs` API, for future-based, lazy, easy-to-model asynchrony that makes it easy to manipulate the file system.

pageSummary: A Future-wrapped `fs` API, for future-based, lazy, easy-to-model asynchrony that makes it easy to manipulate the file system.

comments.summary: make a file string relative

structure.name: localize
structure.example:
```js
import { localize } from 'file-system'
console.log(`support ${localize('business')}`)
// support ./business
```

comments.summary: Read a file asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value.

curried.name: readFileWithFormatAndCancel
curried.summary: Can be given a file encoding and a cancellation function.
curried.lines:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readFile } from 'file-system'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  readFileWithFormatAndCancel(() => process.exit(), 'utf8', './README.md')
)
```

curried.name: readFileWithCancel
curried.lines:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readFile } from 'file-system'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  readFileWithCancel(() => process.exit(), './README.md')
)
```

curried.name: readFile
curried.lines:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readFile } from 'file-system'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(readFile('./README.md'))
```

comments.summary: Read a JSON file asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value, given a cancellation function

structure.name: readJSONFileWithCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readJSONFile } from 'file-system'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(readJSONFile('./package.json'))
```

comments.summary: Read a JSON file asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value

structure.name: readJSONFile
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readJSONFile } from 'file-system'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(readJSONFile('./package.json'))
```

comments.summary:
Read a glob asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value,
with configuration and a cancellation function.
Configuration is passed to [glob](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob)

structure.name: readDirWithConfigAndCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readDirWithConfigAndCancel } from 'file-system'
// [...]
pipe(
  fork(console.warn)(console.log)
)(readDirWithConfigAndCancel(cancellationFn, { ignore: ['node_modules/**'] }, 'src/*'))
```

comments.summary:
Read a glob asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value, with configuration.
Configuration is passed to [glob](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob)

structure.name: readDirWithConfig
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readDirWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
pipe(
  fork(console.warn)(console.log)
)(readDirWithConfig({ ignore: ['node_modules/**'] }, 'src/*'))
```

comments.summary:
Read a glob asynchronously as a Future-wrapped value, default config assumed.
Configuration is passed to [glob](https://www.npmjs.com/package/glob)

structure.name: readDir
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { readDir } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(readDir('src/*'))
```

comments.summary:
Write to a file, with configuration and a cancellation function.
Unlike `fs.writeFile`, this will return the written value as a Future-wrapped value.

structure.name: writeFileWithConfigAndCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { writeFileWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  writeFileWithConfigAndCancel(
    cancellationFunction,
    { ...fs.writeFileConfig },
    'my-file.txt',
    'hey I am a file'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Write to a file, with configuration.
Unlike `fs.writeFile`, this will return the written value as a Future-wrapped value.

structure.name: writeFileWithConfig
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { writeFileWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  writeFileWithConfig(
    { encoding: 'utf8' },
    'my-file.txt',
    'hey I am a file'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Write to a file, assuming `'utf8'`.
Unlike `fs.writeFile`, this will return the written value as a Future-wrapped value.

structure.name: writeFile
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { writeFileWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  writeFileWithConfig(
    'my-file.txt',
    'hey I am a file'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Remove a file, configurably, with cancellation.
Unlike `fs.rm`, this returns the path of the deleted file as a Future-wrapped string.

structure.name: removeFileWithConfigAndCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { removeFileWithConfigAndCancel } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  removeFileWithConfigAndCancel(
    cancellationFn,
    { ...fs.removeFileConfig },
    'my-file.txt'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Remove a file, configurably.
Unlike `fs.rm`, this returns the path of the deleted file as a Future-wrapped string.

structure.name: removeFileWithConfig
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { removeFileWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  removeFileWithConfig(
    { ...fs.removeFileConfig },
    'my-file.txt'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Remove a file.
Unlike `fs.rm`, this returns the path of the deleted file as a Future-wrapped string.

structure.name: removeFile

comments.summary: Remove multiple files, configurably, with a cancellation function.

structure.name: removeFilesWithConfigAndCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { removeFilesWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  removeFilesWithConfigAndCancel(
    cancellationFn,
    { parallel: 30 },
    [...list, ...of, ...thirty, ...files]
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Remove multiple files, configurably.

structure.name: removeFilesWithConfig
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { DEFAULT_REMOVAL_CONFIG, removeFilesWithConfig } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  removeFilesWithConfig(
    DEFAULT_REMOVAL_CONFIG,
    [...list, ...of, ...thirty, ...files]
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Remove multiple files, configurably.

structure.name: removeFilesWithConfig

comments.summary:
Make a directory, given a cancellation function.
Returns a Future-wrapped file path as a discrete value upon success.

structure.name: mkdirWithCancel
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { mkdirWithCancel } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  mkdirWithCancel(
    () => {},
    {},
    'my-dir'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Make a directory
Returns a Future-wrapped file path as a discrete value upon success.

structure.name: mkdir
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { mkdir } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  mkdir(
    {},
    'my-dir'
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Make a directory, recursively.
Returns a Future-wrapped file path as a discrete value upon success.

structure.name: mkdirp
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { mkdir } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  mkdir(
    {},
    'my-dir'
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Write a file to a nested folder and automatically create needed folders, akin to `mkdir -p`

structure.name: writeFileWithAutoPath
structure.example:
```js
import { fork } from 'fluture'
import { writeFileWithAutoPath } from 'file-system'
// [...]
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  writeFileWithAutoPath(
    "folders/you/must/exist/file.biz",
    "my cool content"
  )
)
```

comments.summary:
Generic comparison function.
This can be used to create a number of other more complex functions.

structure.name: equalishBy

pageSummary: Call external processes and consume them as a Future-wrapped value. This is a light wrapper around `execa`, so please see [execa](https://github.com/sindresorhus/execa)'s documentation for more info.

comments.summary:
@pageSummary Call external processes and consume them as a Future-wrapped value.
This is a light wrapper around `execa`, so please see [execa](https://github.com/sindresorhus/execa)'s documentation for more info.

pageSummary: Call external processes and consume them as a Future-wrapped value.
This is a light wrapper around `execa`, so please see [execa](https://github.com/sindresorhus/execa)'s documentation for more info.

comments.summary: Consume external commands as a Future-wrapped value.

curried.name: execWithConfig
curried.summary: Passes all possible configuration values plus a cancellation function.
curried.lines:
```js
import { execWithConfig } from 'kiddo'
import { fork } from 'fluture'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  execWithConfig(
    function customCancellationFunction() {},
    'echo',
    { cleanup: true },
    ['ahoy']
  )
)
```

curried.name: execWithCancel
curried.summary: Eschews any configuration and instead only expects a cancellation function, command and arguments.
curried.lines:
```js
import { execWithCancel } from 'kiddo'
import { fork } from 'fluture'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  execWithCancel(
    function customCancellationFunction() {},
    'echo',
    ['ahoy']
  )
)
```

curried.name: exec
curried.summary: Eschews any configuration or cancellation function. Needs only command and arguments.
curried.lines:
```js
import { exec } from 'kiddo'
import { fork } from 'fluture'
fork(console.warn)(console.log)(
  exec(
    'echo',
    ['ahoy']
  )
)
```

comments.summary: Slice a string by counted delimiters

structure.name: nthIndex
structure.example:
```js test=true
expect(
  nthIndex('/', -5, 'a/b/c/d/e/f/g/h/i/j')
).toEqual("f/g/h/i/j")
```

comments.summary: A simple memoized utility for repeating a string and joining the array.

structure.name: strepeat
structure.example:
```js test=true
expect(strepeat('=', 5)).toEqual('=====')
```

pageSummary: Built-in helpers for making custom plugins more robust. The "helpers" are the third parameter passed to a custom plugin's function.

comments.summary: @pageSummary Built-in helpers for making custom plugins more robust. The "helpers" are the third parameter passed to a custom plugin's function.

pageSummary: Built-in helpers for making custom plugins more robust. The "helpers" are the third parameter passed to a custom plugin's function.
structure.name: helpers

comments.summary: Use this helper to test a regex that matches against any single incidence on any line

structure.name: any

comments.summary: Use this helper to test a regex that matches and filters against every line

structure.name: lines

comments.summary: Use this helper to test a regex that matches and finds the first matching line

structure.name: line

comments.summary: Use this helper to test a regex that matches and finds the last matching line

structure.name: lastLine

comments.summary: Use this helper to select content between two repeating regular expressions

structure.name: between

comments.summary: Use this helper to select all content between two repeating regular expressions

structure.name: selectAll

comments.summary: Use this helper to easily reduce over all lines and aggregate a value

structure.name: reduce

comments.summary: Use this helper to easily filter all lines related to a given regular expression

structure.name: filter

comments.summary: The `config` value is patched in so that it is easier to pass values from the rulefile configuration to the plugins themselves, scoped to the plugin name.

structure.name: config
